sentences.sentence: As Canadians wait to see just what will be in the first federal budget in more than two years, this much is certain: the volume of red ink will surge past any other deficit records in Canada's modern history.What's less certain is whether Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland plans to put Canada on a path back to fiscal sanity or instead risk a dangerous double-down on sky-high spending.With the most recent estimate projecting the deficit for 2020 at $360 billion(https://pbo-dpb.s3.ca-central-1.amazonaws.com/artefacts/923ac2d46e9e3f74e58ed697dffd79237d497232daed02d5078abb52377b4da3) and the prime minister insisting "the last thing Canadians need is to see a rise in taxes right now," Freeland will have to find savings if we are ever going to see a balanced budget again.The first obvious step towards getting there will be ensuring that temporary COVID-19 spending truly was temporary.In 2020, Ottawa spent $271 billion on pandemic-related measures.
The Parliamentary Budget Office believes it can get back to the pre-COVID-19 deficits without too much difficulty.

But for that to happen, the temporary spending measures must be wound down and the government needs to avoid replacing them with expensive new permanent programs.Unfortunately, it's not as if the Trudeau government had a strong fiscal track record before the word "pandemic" became a part of our everyday vocabulary.

In breaking its 2015 promise to balance the budget, the Liberals "increased real per-person federal government spending by nearly 18 per cent during its first term in office," according(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/blogs/prime-ministers-and-government-spending-2021-edition) to Jake Fuss and Nathaniel Li of the Fraser Institute.In fact, the spending spree pushed the government's 2019 expenditures to heights never before seen in Canada's modern age, with the feds spending more(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/blogs/prime-ministers-and-government-spending-2021-edition) in real per capita terms than they did during any single year during the Second World War, Korean War, or during recessions in the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s.With these record levels of spending and a once-unimaginable $1-trillion debt tab, politicians will have to begin answering some tough questions if we're ever going to climb out of this hole and avoid tax hikes.Start at the top.

Should our MPs really be pocketing two pay raises(https://lop.parl.ca/sites/ParlInfo/default/en_CA/People/Salaries) during COVID-19, ranging from $6,900 for a backbench MP to $13,800 for the prime minister?Isn't it time for government employees to share some of the burden?
Many Canadians outside of government have taken pay cuts or lost their jobs.
But government employees have largely gotten through the downturn unscathed.

In fact, the federal government has no records of its unionized employees ever receiving a pay cut, according to research(https://www.secondstreet.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Policy-brief---The-last-government-pay-cut-Final.pdf) from Secondstreet.org.Does the CBC really need $1.3 billion from taxpayers, especially when it has seven vice-presidents, 10 directors-general and five directors of finance?Should the Governor General really be able to bill taxpayers into her afterlife?
Do we need the $20-billion equalization scheme to keep increasing every year?

Do we want politicians who couldn't balance the budget of a lemonade stand trying to pick business winners and losers while handing out subsidies?Philip Cross: If I were finance minister...(https://financialpost.com/opinion/philip-cross-if-i-were-finance-minister)Terence Corcoran: From beer to billionaires, massive tax grabs are here(https://financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-from-beer-to-billionaires-massive-tax-grabs-are-here)Matthew Lau: If I were finance minister...(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-if-i-were-finance-minister)Opinion: Beware the siren song of Modern Monetary Theory(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-beware-the-siren-song-of-modern-monetary-theory)The last point will be key for Canada's finances moving forward.

With Freeland herself acknowledging the saving done by households during the pandemic, we definitely don't need politicians to be throwing out more so-called stimulus to get the economy firing again.Instead, politicians should look at removing costly interprovincial trade barriers, cutting red tape around pipelines, ending the discriminatory tanker ban, scrapping the carbon tax and looking at other forms of tax relief that leave more money in Canadians' pockets.Canada's finances look depressingly bleak.
It's imperative that Freeland start the tough work of winding down temporary pandemic spending, avoiding expensive new permanent programs, and finding ways to reduce the size and cost of government.
If she doesn't, Canadians may end up drowning in a sea of red ink.Franco Terrazzano is the Alberta director and Aaron Wudrick the federal director of the Canadian Taxpayers Federation.
